messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, It is an interesting comparison.   Compare the details of the shape, the raising of the rim, the carving and the hitsu ana. Jim Hi Jim, all - When posting
messages.messageBody:
Ron,

It is an interesting comparison. Compare the details of the shape, the raising of the rim, the carving and the hitsu ana.

Jim



Hi Jim, all -

When posting my thoughts on the latest (#3) tsuba kantei (Nobuiye) I mentioned that the example tsuba reminded me of a tsuba of mine made by Jirotaro Naokatsu (shinshin-to swordsmith). Taking a look at that tsuba today, I was rather impressed with faithfulness that Naokatsu followed to reproduce the work of Nobuiye. I've posted a (less than quality?) photo of the Naokatsu for you to see:

http://tinyurl.com/rs6hm

Notice the lumpy "bones" at the edge of the tsuba at 10 o'clock. Shodai Naokatsu added "bones" to the surface of his tsuba and these can be seen at 1 o'clock and 5 o'clock positions. Notice the similar "plum blossom" design also used by him, no exact, but similar to the Nobuiye. (My tsuba--about 88 mm--is slightly smaller than the kantie Nobuiye. Mine is NBTHK papered.)

Neat comparison!

Ron
STLI

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Very handsome tsuba, Ron.  And an interesting homage to Nobuiye. Cool to see the Kantei piece and yours in such close proximity, especially given the motif
messages.messageBody:
Very handsome tsuba, Ron. And an interesting homage to Nobuiye.
Cool to see the Kantei piece and yours in such close proximity,
especially given the motif similarities... Nice guard.

Steven

Notice the similar "plum blossom" design also used by him, no exact, but similar to the Nobuiye. (My tsuba--about 88 mm--is slightly smaller than the kantie Nobuiye. Mine is NBTHK papered.)

messages.subject: Re: tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Barry -- The technique is called yakite shitate and involves the tsuba to be placed into the furnace until the surface slightly melts.  This produces a
messages.messageBody:
Hi Barry -- The technique is called 'yakite shitate' and involves the
tsuba to be placed into the furnace until the surface slightly
melts. This produces a glaze like finish. It's most remembered in
the kanayama school pieces but used in others.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Ron, There is a Naokatsu tsuba currently on sale at Aoi Art: FO550 - March 17, I quite like these copies, I had one by Gassan Sadakazu which attempted to copy
messages.messageBody:
Ron,
There is a Naokatsu tsuba currently on sale at Aoi Art: FO550 - March 17, I quite like these copies, I had one by Gassan Sadakazu which attempted to copy Nobuie's glazed surface.
Alan

----- Original Message -----
From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, March 18, 2006 7:35 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3


Jim -

Funny, but this work reminded me somewhat of Jirotaro Naokatsu is style. Realizing he copied Nobuie and seeing the super quality of this wonderful tsuba, I go along with the Nobuie call for it. (Sorry, Naokatsu san)

Interesting treatment of the very large/very small-ish hitsu-ana. I would find it interesting to read more comment on that particular feature "in general."

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, March 16, 2006 11:18 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3


Hi Jim,

I may have seen this one before, but I will go ahead and give an
opinion. The manner in which the tsuba is "dished out" with the plate
narrower at the center and then gradually thickening towards the rim is
the first strong identification feature. Next, the obvious hammer work,
giving the tsuba both a wonderful texture and great strength is another
strong feature, along with the beaten over rim. The deep purple, black
color and the shallow carvings are also very strong features of this
artist's work. The soft rounding of the work in the surface is also
classic for this man. The mokko shape is also typical of this worker.
The combination of small and large filled hitsu indicate a fairly early
guard -- late Muromachi to Momoyama period. The particularly small
kogai hitsu would go well with Ko-Mino kogai, some of which are
extremely narrow. Given these attributes and the early date, there is
only one possible maker and that is Nobuie. I suspect it has a juyo
rating as well. A wonderful piece.

Gordon

the first strong identification feature. Next, the obvious hammer work,

classic for this man. The mokko shape is also typical of this worker.
The combination of small and large filled hitsu indicate a fairly early

extremely narrow. Given these attributes and the early date, there is

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Alan and Blokes n Sheilas, Glazed surface .  Now that s interesting.  How was the glaze produced??  For such a feature to have lasted a few centuries it
messages.messageBody:
Alan and Blokes 'n' Sheilas,

"Glazed surface". Now that's interesting. How was the glaze produced?? For
such a feature to have lasted a few centuries it must be very hard, which
suggests to me that it was produced by heating the tsuba in a furnace to induce
an oxidation on the surface that became "the glaze". If chemically induced it
would show wear, surely. Just some mild speculation over my breakfast oats...

Barry Thomas.

----- Original Message -----
From: "Alan Bale" <abale@...>
To: <nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Sunday, March 19, 2006 7:12 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3


Ron,
There is a Naokatsu tsuba currently on sale at Aoi Art: FO550 - March 17, I
quite like these copies, I had one by Gassan Sadakazu which attempted to copy
Nobuie's glazed surface.
Alan

From: Ron Hartmann
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, March 18, 2006 7:35 PM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba kantei 3


Jim -

Funny, but this work reminded me somewhat of Jirotaro Naokatsu is style.
Realizing he copied Nobuie and seeing the super quality of this wonderful tsuba,
I go along with the Nobuie call for it. (Sorry, Naokatsu san)

Interesting treatment of the very large/very small-ish hitsu-ana. I would find
it interesting to read more comment on that particular feature "in general."

Ron
STL

messages.subject: Re:tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Dear Jim and all When I first looked I thought it was a tosho (tsuba made by a sword smith), it also had the field of a tempo with out the stamps (do tempo
messages.messageBody:
Dear Jim and all

When I first looked I thought it was a tosho (tsuba made by a sword
smith), it also
had the field of a tempo with out the stamps (do tempo have to have stamps?)
Also had the look of some Myochin in the carving so the surface work seem
to be no as refine as an example of Kiyofusa (Myochin) in Japanese sword
guard Artists by Murtha

But more like Nobuiye as found in a sales catalog I have from 1982 and
in Haynes #7 catalog #37 there
is another Nobuiye that has the same feel. I also saw some Saotome that
also look close.

So I think that it is a Saotome in the style of Nobuiye.

Can I do that??

Now why does it have such a large hitsuana.

Now I will go read the other quesses

later
david


--
David McDonald Collector of Japanese Swords and Old Iron
PO Box 265 WEB page - http://www.montanairon.com
Sidney MT 59270 email - jswords@...
406-482-3243 evenings I do tsukamaki (wrapping of sword hilts)

Owner of White IH Cub & Super A Farmall, IH 100 & 130, 140, AC G
McD type M, Monitor, Frost King and other stationary engines.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: I m going to take a chance and be more specific.  I would guess that this tsuba is signed Nobuiye, with the hanare style of mei (also called Gamei). The
messages.messageBody:
I'm going to take a chance and be more specific. I would guess that this tsuba is signed "Nobuiye," with the hanare style of mei (also called Gamei).

The tsuba is obviously Nobuiye: yakita shitate (looking glazed) surface, with surface-hammered ji mon engraving.

I attribute it to the hanare signature Nobuiye, because of its subtle and dignified overall appearance. The mokko shape adds to the likelihood of it being that Nbuiye.

DZ.
----- Original Message -----
From: Jim Gilbert
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, March 16, 2006 6:58 PM
Subject: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3


The photos for kantei problem number three can be viewed here:

http://ph.groups.yahoo.com/group/nihontostudy/photos/browse/3108

Jim

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] tsuba kantei 3
messages.msgSnippet: Jim et al - Not having read any other post...I think from the shape, color, surface treatment, and very strong rim that we are looking at an Edo period Nobuie.
messages.messageBody:
Jim et al -
Not having read any other post...I think from the shape, color, surface
treatment, and very strong rim that we are looking at an Edo period Nobuie.
Without looking at any references, I will say this is the Edo group, since
I can't recall where the others were based.
MHO
-t

messages.messageBody:
Erratum- delete Kaneie, I was fooling myself. Nobuie or
Yamakichibei, which one shows characteristics that best describe
this piece? Nobu, Yama, Nobu, Yama ? Nobuie features it best. Seems
like I'm part of a crowd. John
